articles.title: More micromobility layoffs, digging into the Mobileye S1 and a Rivian recall
articles.description: Reminder, that I will be in San Francisco for TechCrunch Disrupt.  A New York City Council member is pushing a bill that will allow New Yorkers to benefit...
articles.content: The Station is a weekly newsletter dedicated to all things transportation.Sign up here just click The Station to receive the full edition of the newsletter every weekend in your inbox. This is a sho [+7923 chars]
articles.summary: You also can send a direct message to @kirstenkorosecThe big news of this week was, sadly, more layoffs in the micromobility world.Tier laid off about 10% of its Spin staff, including a number of executives. One industry insider told TechCrunch that might be because Tier can handle many of those tasks, but would still need help on the ground when it decides to send over its new e-scooters.The micromobility sector has struggled in 2022. Many of those layoffs occurred over the summer, but now it seems another wave of layoffs is washing over the industry.Spin wasnt the only micromobility company that has made cuts this month. * Two of my favorite things  public transit and micromobility.A New York City Council member is pushing a bill that will allow New Yorkers to benefit from ratting out owners of vehicles blocking bike lanes or entrances/exits of school buildings, sidewalks and crosswalks. The Aussie company downsized its global workforce by 16%.In other news Barcelona is doing a one-year pilot project using the energy recovered from metro trains braking to charge personal e-scooters. Welcome back to The Station, your central hub for all past, present and future means of moving people and packages from Point A to Point B. Welp, this week delivered a firehose of news. The Stations weekly emailed newsletter has a lot more on EVs and AVs, future of flight, insider info and more.
articles.html_summary:
• You also can send a direct message to @kirstenkorosecThe big news of this week was, sadly, more layoffs in the micromobility world.Tier laid off about 10% of its Spin staff, including a number of executives.
  • One industry insider told TechCrunch that might be because Tier can handle many of those tasks, but would still need help on the ground when it decides to send over its new e-scooters.The micromobility sector has struggled in 2022.
  • Many of those layoffs occurred over the summer, but now it seems another wave of layoffs is washing over the industry.Spin wasn’t the only micromobility company that has made cuts this month.
  • * Two of my favorite things — public transit and micromobility.A New York City Council member is pushing a bill that will allow New Yorkers to benefit from ratting out owners of vehicles blocking bike lanes or entrances/exits of school buildings, sidewalks and crosswalks.
  • The Aussie company downsized its global workforce by 16%.In other news …Barcelona is doing a one-year pilot project using the energy recovered from metro trains braking to charge personal e-scooters.
  • Welcome back to The Station, your central hub for all past, present and future means of moving people and packages from Point A to Point B. Welp, this week delivered a firehose of news.

articles.author: Alison Snyder
articles.title: AI is helping materials scientists home in on promising new materials
articles.description: AI and automation are speeding up science and chemistry by helping scientists pick which experiments to conduct and home in on promising new materials.Why it matters Theres pressure on these fields to produce new materials faster and cheaper to support and
articles.content: AI and automation are speeding up science and chemistry by helping scientists pick which experiments to conduct and home in on promising new materials.Why it matters Theres pressure on these fiel [+5279 chars]
articles.summary: AI and automation are speeding up science and chemistry by helping scientists pick which experiments to conduct and home in on promising new materials.Why it matters: There's pressure on these fields to produce new materials faster and cheaper to support and power technologies that could transform industries and economies. A neural network then whittles that down to about 1,000 remaining candidates.What they found: The researchers identified two new alloys in six times through the loop.Yes, but: Finding a material or chemical is one hurdle.
articles.html_summary: • AI and automation are speeding up science and chemistry by helping scientists pick which experiments to conduct and home in on promising new materials.Why it matters: There's pressure on these fields to produce new materials faster and cheaper to support and power technologies that could transform industries and economies.

articles.title: AG is among 4 finalists for Northern New Mexico College post
articles.description: New Mexico Attorney General Hector Balderas is a finalist for president of Northern New Mexico College. Hes one of four people being considered for the post, along with Dr. Patricia Trujillo, the deputy secretary of the states Higher Education Department.

articles.html_summary: • Michelle Lujan Grisham as deputy secretary of the Higher Education Department in 2020 and supervises six of nine divisions including academic policy, adult education and information technology.Hicks is high-ranking administrator at Dalton State— Georgia’s only Hispanic-serving institution — while Johns has been president at Ferrum College since 2018.

articles.author: Kyle Wiggers
articles.title: Is the RPA market in trouble?
articles.description: Automation Anywhere, one of the largest RPA vendors, raised debt instead of equity. Is that cause for alarm in the market?
articles.content: Automation Anywhere, one of the bestfunded RPA providers with over $1 billion capital raised to date, went the debt route this week, securing a $200 million loan from Silicon Valley Bank, SVB Capita [+1571 chars]
articles.summary: Assuming the $2.9 billion figure comes to pass, itd translate to 19.5% growth between the years 2021 and 2022.

articles.author: Kyle Wiggers
articles.title: Trendsi secures $25M to help sellers and manufacturers predict demand
articles.description: Trendsi, which applies AI and machine learning to predict inventory needs for sellers and manufacturers, has raised $25 million in capital.
articles.content: In the traditional businesstobusiness world, sellers often dont know how much of a product they should order. Even at wellrun companies, anywhere from 20% to 30% of inventory is either dead (i.e.  [+4600 chars]
articles.summary: Zhang tells TechCrunch that the new cash will be put toward investments in data infrastructure, supply chain technology, new merchandise categories and international expansion.We are building a new platform that lowers the barrier for anyone to start selling online or offline, Zhang told TechCrunch in an email interview. [This] allows retailers to only take minimum and no inventory risk by building our inventory and sales forecasting models and offering the drop-shipping service, Zhang explained. Using data collected on the platform and from third parties, Trendsi attempts to predict sales down to the SKU level, so that sellers can reduce excess inventory and ideally prevent out-of-stock issues. Beyond this, the platform taps sales and behavioral data to curate and recommend products to sellers.Recently, Trendsi launched a feature it calls just-in-time manufacturing, which aims to help manufacturers quickly restock based on real-time sales data and predictions. Xia was one of the first employees at e-scooter startup Lime and previously worked as an analyst at a16z (Andreessen Horowitz).Zhang, Xia and Trendsis third co-founder, Maddie Davidson, sought with Trendsi to build a service that applies AI and machine learning to streamline tasks like inventory and sales forecasting. Retail business leaders expect AI will have the biggest impact in customer intelligence, inventory management and chatbots for customer service, creating a virtuous adoption-investment cycle in the coming years. This pandemic has revealed the real costs associated with inventory mismanagement.
articles.html_summary:
• Zhang tells TechCrunch that the new cash will be put toward investments in data infrastructure, supply chain technology, new merchandise categories and international expansion.“We are building a new platform that lowers the barrier for anyone to start selling online or offline,” Zhang told TechCrunch in an email interview.
  • “[This] allows retailers to only take minimum and no inventory risk by building our inventory and sales forecasting models and offering the drop-shipping service,” Zhang explained.
  • Using data collected on the platform and from third parties, Trendsi attempts to predict sales down to the SKU level, so that sellers can reduce excess inventory and ideally prevent out-of-stock issues.
  • Beyond this, the platform taps sales and behavioral data to curate and recommend products to sellers.Recently, Trendsi launched a feature it calls “just-in-time” manufacturing, which aims to help manufacturers quickly restock based on real-time sales data and predictions.
  • Xia was one of the first employees at e-scooter startup Lime and previously worked as an analyst at a16z (Andreessen Horowitz).Zhang, Xia and Trendsi’s third co-founder, Maddie Davidson, sought with Trendsi to build a service that applies AI and machine learning to streamline tasks like inventory and sales forecasting.
  • Retail business leaders expect AI will have the biggest impact in customer intelligence, inventory management and chatbots for customer service, creating a virtuous adoption-investment cycle in the coming years.

articles.author: Paul Sawers
articles.title: Samsung seeks smart TV growth with first Tizen OS licensing deals
articles.description: Samsung has confirmed the first thirdparty smart TV makers to ship with its Tizen operating system (OS), with several manufacturers preparing to launch Tizenpowered TVs this year across Europe and Australasia. Tizen, for the uninitiated, is a Linuxbase
articles.content: Samsung has confirmed the first thirdparty smart TV makers to ship with its Tizen operating system (OS), with several manufacturers preparing to launch Tizenpowered TVs this year across Europe and  [+2177 chars]
articles.summary: On top of that, all Tizen TVs will be able to access features such as Samsungs virtual assistant Bixby, which ushers voice search into the mix.
articles.html_summary: • On top of that, all Tizen TVs will be able to access features such as Samsung’s virtual assistant Bixby, which ushers voice search into the mix.
